The military factor was quintessential in the rise of problems and crises in the Roman Empire in the third century, but it was itself a function of coinciding developments, including the intensification of actual warfare, epidemics, and a change in the bargaining position of surviving productive people in war areas, who could take refuge in anachoresis.
